column1: #Text=A Happy New Year to you all , my dearest family , which of course includes Mr. L. and a young man by the name of Teddy .
#Text=I ca n't tell you how much I enjoyed your Christmas bundle , for I did n't get it till night and had given up hoping .
#Text=Your letter came in the morning , but you said nothing about a parcel , meaning it for a surprise , so I was disappointed , for I 'd had a ' kind of feeling ' that you would n't forget me .
#Text=I felt a little low in my mind as I sat up in my room after tea , and when the big , muddy , battered-looking bundle was brought to me , I just hugged it and pranced .
#Text=It was so homey and refreshing that I sat down on the floor and read and looked and ate and laughed and cried , in my usual absurd way .
#Text=The things were just what I wanted , and all the better for being made instead of bought .
#Text=Beth 's new ' ink bib ' was capital , and Hannah 's box of hard gingerbread will be a treasure .
#Text=I 'll be sure and wear the nice flannels you sent , Marmee , and read carefully the books Father has marked .
#Text=Speaking of books reminds me that I 'm getting rich in that line , for on New Year 's Day Mr. Bhaer gave me a fine Shakespeare .

#Text=It is one he values much , and I 've often admired it , set up in the place of honor with his German Bible , Plato , Homer , and Milton , so you may imagine how I felt when he brought it down , without its cover , and showed me my own name in it , " from my friend Friedrich Bhaer " .
#Text=" You say often you wish a library .
